THE PRINCE ALBERT TIMES
AND SASKATCHEWAN REVIEW.

PRINCE ALBERT, SASK., FRIDAY, JANUARY 30, 1886.

Banking House at Macarthur & Knowles, Prince Albert, N.W.T.
Notices of the Hon. W. A. Mellen, Barrister-at-Law, Prince Albert.
Notice. All parties interested in us are requested to give notice that when their amounts will be handed over for our account, we intend discharging the mortgage of our present undertaking.
Notice. Notice is hereby given that the Secretary and Solicitors—Partnership Solicitors—of the Royal and Provincial Bankruptcy Court—will apply for the dissolution of the company under the provisions of the Bankruptcy Act.
Public Notice. Public Notice is hereby given by the lieutenant-governor of the North West Territories, and is directed to all persons who may be interested herein, that the provisions enumerated in this order are directed against any party engaged in the transportation of goods by land in a province within those limits, or hereafter to be permitted, who shall not make such proof as the lieutenant-governor may deems necessary.

FRIDAY, JANUARY 30, 1885.

Another victim of tea-totalism—Chief Running Wolf was only back in his own country before ten when any other squaw in camp could have challenged him to an open fight. Chief Running Wolf's squaw was five months along, when in the act of taking the tea from her mother's lips she died. Now it is evident that had the liquor been intoxicating, that child could never have happened, as the deceased lady must have been unconscious before doing herself any harm.

Some provisions of the Canadian Fishery Act have been extended to Manitoba and North-West relating to white fish and trout. It seems curious that this should not be advertised more widely as it will affect a vast number of classes in the Territories, who, as a rule, seem to be very fond of the matter. But kind of change is rather too sweeping in its application to a country like this, nor do we think the people of this district, many of whom can hardly keep body and soul together without any interference with what to many is absolutely a necessity of life, viz.—their winter supply of white fish.

The people of Prince Albert have always been very liberal, especially to charity. It would be a great act of charity if the government would intercede among the Indians near the river, and see what state they are in, and if they are not able to get their food, to send them some flour or hard up. Some apply to Mr. Moffat for supplies, but he has no authority to lend them. The Indians are a great deal worse off than they are as they do, but it would not say much for the people of this town if they actually knew that within a radius of half a mile their fellow men are dying of starvation.

It is rumored that Chaplain, sheriff of the North West Territories will succeed the late F. H. Emms as secretary of public works, and it is said the Government will not increase the North West Mounted Police.

A Canadian Pacific train drawn by two locomotives ran into a train of flat cars 25 miles from Montreal. The locomotives were wrecked, the passenger cars derailed, and the occupants of the cars badly shaken up. The loss to the company is very heavy.

The ice palace and the comittee at Montreal are being pushed on rapidly in readiness for the opening day.

The Canadian Pacific Railway say a plot is on foot in New York to help their securities.

Hearing Piles—Symptoms and Treatment.

The symptoms are headache like pericarditis, nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea, constipation, very distressing, particularity at night; sickness and pinworms were also present. The patient said that the private parts are sometimes affected. It allowed us to examine very serious results.

A BIG COAL FIELD.

Professor Newton, a practical American geologist who has been prospecting in this country for a number of months, and who discovered the immense coal mine at Crowfoot Crossing, arrived in the city last week. Mr. Newton has been engaged by the professor since morning, and the latter gave some particulars regarding the coal.

"The coal," said the professor, "shows the least percentage of water of any coal west of the Rocky Mountains. So far as we have discovered, no coal is exactly adapted for that purpose; and for particular purposes it cannot be improved upon. I found it and found no sulphur in it so that any quantity could be stored in woods without any danger of ignition. You know great trouble is experienced with some coal in consequence of its aptness to ignite, charring in a few minutes. Now, if such was discovered near the Crowfoot Crossing, would be worth $10,000 an acre in the Western States. There is sufficient coal here to keep the whole North-West warm for a million years.

I consider there is enough coal there to last all the world for centuries. The seam is over four feet thick, which is much larger than almost any seam in United States. The shaft is 135 feet deep and eight feet in diameter. Over the seam is a stratum of stone more than five feet thick. This will make an excellent roof for the mine. There are several other seams encountered on the way down, but none of them are so good and none near so thick as the bottom seam."

The proprietor is confident that if the mines were developed the coal would be used to supply Dakota, Montana and Minnesota. He thinks it would soon supplant all other fuel in those states. While the shaft for the coal is very thin, the stone four feet thick, of a very rich character was struck. Professor Newton says it possesses untold wealth, and if its richness were made known, a sensation among capitalists would be created.

THE SCORING FOR THE RACE.

To the Editor of the Times,

Sir,—I am sorry to say that any man who would have the audacity to go to your office and falsify the score of some of the men that took part in the race last night, is unworthy of your notice. I was also surprised at you for charging the score without the consent of the judges and all parties interested. If the race club are going to allow a false vote hereafter, scores should be kept by the best method possible.

Such conduct would not be tolerated among savages, much less in a civilized community. When Mr. Cherry was called Mr. F. Cherry's name was nine miles and five laps, not eight miles and fourteen laps, as stated in your paper of the 23rd inst. Every man entitled to his rights, so Mr. Cherry entitled to nine miles and five laps in the last race.

Yours, &c.,
O. C. MacLeod.

Saucer.

Mr. MacLeod seems to be really surprised, and as we do not wish to surprise him any more, we will let him go by without saying that he ruined the score from a gentleman whom we would not care to implicate the charge of falsifying.

CANADIAN.

OTTAWA, Jan. 18.—The writ for the Dominion election in Saskatoon has been issued.

Sir Leonard Tilley has been forbidden by his doctors to go out after midnight.

John Macdonald, nominated for the Legislature against Darling Reform, has retired from the contest.

EMMANUEL COLLEGE

PRINCIPAL:

The Rev. W. R. FLETT, B.A.,

Cantab., Late Foundation Scholar of Sydney College, England.

THE NEXT TERM BEGINS ON

Monday, January 12th.

Besides the ordinary subjects read at a Public School, each pupil is taught the Elements of Scientific Agriculture.

A Laboratory is provided, where the Principles of Elementary Qualitative and Quantitative Chemical Analysis are taught.

Special Evening Lectures to Students Reading for the Matriculation Examination of the University of Saskatchewan.

For further particulars apply to the

REV. THE PRINCIPAL,

Emmanuel College, Prince Albert, Sask.

1879.

Buffalo Hall!

CARD OF THANKS.

During the whole time we have been in business we never have had a more successful holiday season than the one just past. Our sales have been large and of a substantial character, and we feel sure that we have enrolled many new names as regular customers. Such a state of affairs is impossible except to something as it does that our continued efforts to provide the best of everything in our line at the least possible cost have been so generally appreciated.

To all who have patronized us, not only during the holiday season but also throughout the whole of 1884, we beg to tender our sincere thanks and to intimate that a large assortment of Dry Goods, Clothing, Fun and Games is still fresh, well selected and extremely varied, and in order to clear up before spring trade every department has been overhauled and articles marked at clearing sale prices.

BETTS & GYNNIE.

Prince Albert - N.W.T
THE MAIL ROBBER.

CHICAGO, Jan. 16.—A well-known horse thief yesterday was arrested at a well-known gambling house in Chicago, a man of 35 years old, who claimed to be a nephew of Sir Alexander Campbell, M.P., of Dundee. Sir Alexander Campbell, however, has been in London for some time, so the claim cannot be true. The man was arrested by the police, and it is said that he was carrying a large amount of money when he was apprehended. He was taken to the police station, where he was questioned about his activities. It is believed that he was involved in a number of thefts in the city, and he was charged with grand larceny. He was held without bail until his arraignment in court.

STEWART BROS., TRADERS, GENERAL MERCHANTS,

On Thursday the return match was played between the Argyle and Saskatoon Curling Clubs, on the rink of the former, and resulted in favor of the Saskatoon by our side. The game was very exciting.
